awd_titl_txt: CSBR: Ownership Transfer. Rescuing three imperiled Kentucky herbaria and integrating them into the Mid-South's most active herbarium at Austin Peay State University (APSC)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made to Austin Peay State University (APSU), a mid-sized, public institution in Clarksville, TN to acquire the Western KY University (WKU) herbarium. This rescued collection will be merged with that of APSU to create a 120,000-specimen research-quality collection that will serve the multi-state region between the Appalachian and Ozark Mountains. APSU's herbarium is the primary repository for central and western TN - a region centered on the southern half of the Interior Plateaus (IP) biodiversity hotspot - one of the most diverse land-locked regions of the Northern Hemisphere. The WKU collections (68,000 specimens) represent the northern half of this diversity hotspot. The rescued WKU collection will be curated, secured and the specimens will be made accessible via online resources to scientists, conservationists, students, and the public. Simultaneously, the consolidation of the two collections will allow APSU to enhance its leadership in training field biologists through unique collections-based educational opportunities. Many of the beneficiaries of APSU's programs are women, first generation college students, low-income, and active-duty military students. These individuals will benefit from APSU's demonstrated a commitment to building a collections-based training program for research biologists, land managers, and conservationists. 

Consolidating the APSU and WKU collections into one facility presents challenges to the existing APSU facility, which has a current maximum capacity of 117,000 specimens in 78 cabinets. The addition of WKU will immediately fill the collection with 123,000 specimens. This award will allow APSU to expand its current compactor storage system to 120 cabinets, increasing maximum storage capacity to 180,000 specimens, leaving ample room for growth from collections-based research. Additionally, funding will support a full-time collections manager, one graduate student research assistant, and three undergraduate students, all of whom will receive training in collections management and research. Full integration of the two herbaria will involve: (1) securing WKU and ensuring its long-term viability by eradicating insect pests, processing backlogged specimens, annotating specimens to updated taxonomy, and properly storing specimens in insect-proof, archival cabinets; (2) using the enlarged research-quality herbarium to enhance training and research on the understudied flora of the Interior Plateaus Ecoregion biodiversity hotspot; and (3) making specimens accessible via databasing and digitization efforts tied to existing web-based interfaces: SERNEC, iDigBio, Symbiota, and APSU (http://nhm.apsu.edu/collections/plants).

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Herbaria are dried plant collections preserved for scientific study. Herbarium collections form the backbone of botany, and are used by scientists (taxonomy, genetics, biogeography) and for conservation purposes (for example mapping species locations, and invasive species).

By 2016, the Western Kentucky University (WKU) herbarium of Bowling Green Kentucky had fallen into disrepair and disuse, with no institutional interest in maintaining the collections. The WKU herbarium represented a signification portion of the botanical collections of Kentucky, having acquired the historic collections from the University of Louisville just a few years earlier. Approximately 68,000 herbarium specimens, the oldest dating back to the 1840s, were in danger of deteriorating from neglect and were unavailable for scientific use.

The funding provided through this grant has ensured that the herbarium collections of Western Kentucky University have been securely transferred to the herbarium of Austin Peay State University of Clarksville Tennessee. As of 2022, all 68,000 specimens from WKU have integrated into the APSU collections.

In 2017, the specimens were first packaged and moved to a secure location in Clarksville. From there, each specimen was:

-Frozen to prevent insect damage

-Carefully checked for identification errors and taxonomic updates

-Photographed

-Uploaded to an online database available for researchers and the public

-Filed in the secure herbarium cabinets at APSU, fully integrated into the collection

This careful and deliberate process applied to all incoming WKU specimens over the course of 2017-2021.

In addition, many specimens (>10,000) were still in a semi-unfinished state when acquired by APSU, particularly the extensive collections of Max Medley. These required APSU to type labels from his handwritten notebooks and mount the plants on the standard cardstock paper used to secure specimens. This slow and time-consuming process was accomplished by the use of hired undergraduate assistants and work-study scholarship students.

The work of transferring the WKU herbarium was accomplished  by the Principle Investigator Dr. Dwayne Estes and the collections manager and supervisor Mason Brock. Together, they were able to secure this important collections for future use. The funding of this grant also provided many opportunities for undergraduate experience in collections, as many hands were needed to process the large amount of plant specimens.

The rescued WKU specimens have also been referenced in scientific journals. Many specimens represented rare species (endangered or threatened), and these localities have now been tracked by conservation agencies. In addition, many thousands of specimens were either misidentified or unidentified. Over the course of this grant, the identity of approximately 10,000 specimens was determined by the collections manager, Mason Brock.

Due to this grant, the historic WKU and Louisville herbarium collections have been safely transferred and secured at Austin Peay State University, and are now fully available online for researchers to use.





Last Modified: 05/01/2022
Modified by: Larry D Estes
